job_title: Behavioral Health Technician in Tampa, FL
pros:
A pro is that you genuinely care about some of the clients and care about their recovery.
It's really an eye opener for those who are attending school and plan to get into a similar profession.

Also, it's my personal opinion that interactions with clients are beneficial to them.

You'll only have one who cares.
cons:
You'll come to notice that counselors and management look down on you because you're BHT. They don't experience all the things you go through and they don't have to deal with. You as a BHT spend more time with the client then they do.

You're not included in company activities, most of the time you're not informed of anything.

There is a lack of consistency from upper management. Overall, you'll try to enforce the rules but its really management/counselors that serves as a disciplining hand. However, they don't enforce all the rules and they don't necessarily back you up. In order for the clients to respect a BHTs request counselors/management  need to enforce and respect the rules as well. I've seen the mentality of other BHTs go down as well. If you're employees do not feel valued what would the outcome be? I suppose poor work ethic as they would feel that they're and work they're doing is pointless.

There isn't enough pay to deal with the verbal abuse and attitudes of clients.

They cannot keep counselors.

Low key racism.

There needs to be a lot more structure. 

It's basically a holding pin, a 24hr daycare. They don't really care about the clients; they care about the funding. 

Dealing with medication when you're not certified to.

Some of the parents are worse than the clients. You'll meet a lot of enablers.

Unprofessional conduct like a counselor informing clients of searches.

review_title: Entry level company to start a career
job_title: IT Help Desk in Tampa, FL
pros: Good team, good holidays, no stress
cons: low pay, needs more structure and equal treatment

review_title: Great co-workers, company tries, but administrators always want a scape goat
pros: I was able to gain a lot of career related experience working at Dacco as they offered a lot of employee trainings.  The majority of my co-workers were great people who enjoyed being able to help others in the community,
cons: The "Third Floor" is not held accountable for some of their actions and decisions.  There seems to be a degree of prejudice going on when it comes to the hiring of management.  Also, the "Third Floor" was unable to accept that when things don't seem to be going smoothly, they need to own their part in the decisions that fostered the problem to begin with rather than seek out scape goats.

review_title: Incompetent Management; "Disposable Worker" Attitude; Run like an Oligarchy
pros:
Great Co-workers; supportive peer networks are formed and utilized effectively.
Clients are overall appreciative of the employees when treated with respect.
Clients are enthusiastic when properly motivated with goal setting and rewards.
cons:
The Burn-out rate is high due to ineffective Managers and Supervisors.
Management puts the Money before the Client's service needs.
Management permits a High Turnover Rate to maintain control the Annual Budget; to limit the quality of the Staff to Client interaction.  Clients are treated like "cattle" for all their services.

pros:
Society in general has had many challenges this year. DACCO Behavior Health has provided support for their employees. Safety guidelines for COVID-19 have been in place and updated accordingly. 

The HR department has provided ongoing activities and support to keep spirits up.
cons: Work can be challenging at times. This isn’t necessarily a bad thing. It can often lead to growth.

pros: Agency has a thorough, comprehensive treatment program designed to treat the whole person; friendly and supportive staff which makes one feel part of a family; administration expresses appreciation and respect for staff members who dutifully complete their tasks; jobs offer a clinically enriching experience for a professional to learn much about human behaviors.
cons: Clinical staff are too burdened with clerical duties which interferes with their energy and time to devote themselves to their clinical work.

pros: If you are working in human services because you have a genuine desire to help people get their lives back then this is a great place to work. There are some of the most kind and compassionate people who work here and really want to help make a difference in the clients lives. Vacation and retirement packages are decent and there are opportunities to learn a lot through the different trainings that are offered.
cons: Constant changes that happen within the company that are never discussed with the staff that are being effected by them. Lack of proper training and resources to effectively do your job. Poor communication between departments which leads to confusion and chaos which is noticeable to the clients. The company says that they want to help one client at a time and claim to stand behind their mission statement but when it comes down to it they serve the almighty dollar. They make allowances for clients who have money but  the ones who really want the help but don't have the funds have to jump through hoops to get it. It's unfortunate because for the prices they expect for these clients to come up with are unrealistic and most walk away feeling they should just continue using because it will probably cost them less. It's sad because what a lot of the leaders forget or dont even think about is thayvwe are dealing with human beings. Living, breathing people who have kids and husbands and wives and the reality is that they might walk out our doors and die. All because they couldn't come up with enouyyygh money to get the help they need y know thayt there is enough funding to  go around. People need to remember why they decided to work in this field or find some other line of work that doesn't have such severe consequences for poor leadership and basis lack of concern for human lives, drug addict or not.

review_title: It's a great place to try and make a difference in someone's life.
pros:
Helping a population that most people do not care about helping. 
Co workers that help each other and try to work as a team despite managements beliefs
Vacation and Holiday pay.
cons:
Favoritism between management staff
Input for positive changes needed  ignored
Building is deteriorating
Salary does not match credentials across the agency regardless of time employed. 
Case loads that are next to impossible to manage. 
Re-evaluating your own ethical beliefs daily due to "management" demands despite the legality of the situation. (BILLING) Auditors are either incompetent or so confused on the BS handed to them, distracted and blinded to the problems or just give up, eat free lunch and leave.

pros: The clients are why we are here because they need our help and you can change a life. We work at a place where we have that opportunity to help people. That's why I stay.
cons: All of us are unsure what to do. I really love my job but we have reached our limit, so several of us are going to be posting reviews. Our main concerns are very low pay, no respect, and people who are not truthful. We want change so we can help the clients but management won't listen to us. It's a very unstable workplace.

review_title: You'll find what you're looking for
pros: Experience, supervision, decent co-workers, centrally located main campus
cons: high caseloads, poor training, sink or swim mentality, poor communication, chronically short staffed, 60 hours of work expected to be completed in 40

pros: I have been working at DACCO for 7 years and find it a great work environment.  The people are the best I have ever worked with in my long career in healthcare. Benefits are competitive with those provided by major employers (I worked for HCA for 17 years prior to DACCO, and Moffitt before that and find benefits as good).   Casual Fridays are great!
cons: Working in the non profit world has it's challenges, due to constant Federal and State funding cuts.

pros:
- good training opportunities
- great co-workers
- good supervisors who care.
cons:
- red tape
- really bad pay
- burn out easily due to listed con reasons. 
-senior management tries their best to circumvent labor laws, see below.
- we have to "pretend" we work only 40 hours. If we work more, and claim it, then we get a reprimand. So...everyone just says they work 40, even if we work more, when all the tasks etc assigned would be well over 45 hrs per week
- keep putting on more stress to counselors by assigning extra tasks ..even if we're already spread thin.

pros: Great place to work, a leader in area not for profits, great leadership!  Many days off and retirement match too.  People are warm and caring about clients and fellow employees! Benefits are good. Free supervision trading  for licensed eligible folks at work!
cons: Wish more people would come experience this workplace, a best kept secret!   Background checks keep some people out that might be great employees for those in recovery.

review_title: work hard but love your job and the company you keep
pros: Nice environment, wonderful job satisfaction in helping people to recover, decent benefits, best treatment facility in our area with excellent results.  There is upward mobility, and that's good.
cons: We deal primarily with indigent people so their resources are not great but helping them is rewarding.

pros: You work with clients who really need help and are thankful to have you. Seeing their small strides gives you motivation.
cons: Paper work paper work and then more paper work. But other than that its a good job and helps people.

review_title: Expected me to run an 80 person homeless shelter for 10 p/ HR
job_title: Behavioral Health Technician in Tampa, FL
pros:
The homeless residents are nice for the most part
It is full time Work
Parking is right in front of the building
cons:
The low pay for working night shift is ridiculous
Tasks expected of you are far too many
Hours are awful 2 to 10pm

review_title: The worst job I have ever had. Extremely high turnover rate.
pros:
Clinical supervision for graduate school, registered internships, credit toward CAP.
Helping some clients and seeing them improve, with the limited time you have to help them.
The people you work side by side with (lateral coworkers, not management) are very friendly and are great team members, probably because we are all going through the same horrible experience.
cons:
Caseload so high it's ridiculous. Management/Staff is inconsistent in holding clients accountable, and sometimes enable clients due to limited time/energy to deal with it. 
Management and CEO are focused on money, numbers, state/national accreditations and Medicaid audits, and liability...not people (that goes for both clients and employees). Extremely disorganized, with horrible communication from the top down.
ZERO training before getting thrown into the fire with a huge caseload.
Extremely low wages. Making less with a master's degree than I did as a lifeguard when I was in high school, less than a server at a restaurant.
Very few clients choose DACCO unless required by court or Dept of Children and Families; because it's so hard to get the care you need here due to staff being stretched so thin.
They don't care if you or your family get sick, if you are pregnant, or if your family member dies...they keep dumping more work onto you to do when you come back from emergency leave, and they will fire you for whatever they want even if you have gone above and beyond what you should have done for the company.

pros:
Valuable work experience 
Great management within department 
Flexible schedule
cons:
Needs more extensive training 
Better pay

pros: Easy to get hired, but I wouldn't recommend it.
cons: The work environment was not supportive, management doesn't fight for the employees and the program used for working with clients is very punitive. That's not what I was taught as a therapist and not how I want my clients to feel when working with them. Good luck if you consider employment with Dacco.
